content.raw: Yeah, interesting, it looks like a floor which has received a texture does not ever become transparent, even though the walls and stairs with textures do.
content.html: Yeah, interesting, it looks like a floor which has received a texture does not ever become transparent, even though the walls and stairs with textures do.

pullrequest.title: Building Editor: Pick wall / floor / stairs texture from a pre-set list on inspector

content.raw: Gotcha! So maybe there is a bug with the floor inspector? I'll take a closer look at the code to see if I can track something down...
content.html: Gotcha! So maybe there is a bug with the floor inspector? I'll take a closer look at the code to see if I can track something down...

pullrequest.title: Building Editor: Pick wall / floor / stairs texture from a pre-set list on inspector

content.raw:
Thanks, this is really taking more time than it should.

I found where the problem lies, not sure how to fix it though. I just realized that setting texture to the floor from the inspector is the only time when texture is set to something and that thing is not fully opaque. When setting it for walls and stairs from the inspector, they are usually selected and thus opaque. But if you open a wall inspector, then deselect the wall, then change the texture on the inspector, the same problem as the floor occurs.

So I guess it's a matter of making sure we `Set3dTransparency` after `Set3dTexture` has been completed.
content.html:
Thanks, this is really taking more time than it should.

I found where the problem lies, not sure how to fix it though. I just realized that setting texture to the floor from the inspector is the only time when texture is set to something and that thing is not fully opaque. When setting it for walls and stairs from the inspector, they are usually selected and thus opaque. But if you open a wall inspector, then deselect the wall, then change the texture on the inspector, the same problem as the floor occurs.

So I guess it's a matter of making sure we Set3dTransparency after Set3dTexture has been completed.

pullrequest.title: Building Editor: Pick wall / floor / stairs texture from a pre-set list on inspector

content.raw: Oh, interesting. It does seem a bit clunky to always call Set3dTransparency after Set3dTexture. We could fold a call to Set3dTransparency into Set3dTexture, but that seems a bit odd too. Does setting the texture reset the underlying transparency value?
content.html: Oh, interesting. It does seem a bit clunky to always call Set3dTransparency after Set3dTexture. We could fold a call to Set3dTransparency into Set3dTexture, but that seems a bit odd too. Does setting the texture reset the underlying transparency value?

pullrequest.title: Building Editor: Pick wall / floor / stairs texture from a pre-set list on inspector

content.raw:
It doesn't seem to reset the transparency, `visual->GetTransparency()` keeps returning the semi-transparent value, even though the visual looks opaque.

I merged this branch with pull request #1308 on branch `hitl_textures_inspector_transp`. There I observed this:

1. Draw a wall, open its inspector, deselect the wall (clicking on the background for example).

2. On the inspector, choose the wooden texture and apply. The wall becomes opaque even though its transparency is still 0.4

3. Select the wall (click on it), deselect it (click outside), it becomes semi-transparent, good.

4. On the inspector, select the tiles and apply, again it is opaque even though it's not selected.

5. Now the fun part: on the inspector, select the wood and apply (the wall is still unselected) - and now it shows semi-transparent - and this happens independently of whether the wall is selected or not. So there's some memory there regarding the materials. When we selected->deselected the wall, the wooden texture for this specific wall only became transparent... I'm still learning about the `rendering::Visual` class, not sure if there's an issue with `Visual::SetMaterial` or I'm just using it wrong. @iche033 ?
content.html:
It doesn't seem to reset the transparency, visual->GetTransparency() keeps returning the semi-transparent value, even though the visual looks opaque.

I merged this branch with pull request #1308 on branch hitl_textures_inspector_transp. There I observed this:

  1. Draw a wall, open its inspector, deselect the wall (clicking on the background for example).

  2. On the inspector, choose the wooden texture and apply. The wall becomes opaque even though its transparency is still 0.4

  3. Select the wall (click on it), deselect it (click outside), it becomes semi-transparent, good.

  4. On the inspector, select the tiles and apply, again it is opaque even though it's not selected.

  5. Now the fun part: on the inspector, select the wood and apply (the wall is still unselected) - and now it shows semi-transparent - and this happens independently of whether the wall is selected or not. So there's some memory there regarding the materials. When we selected->deselected the wall, the wooden texture for this specific wall only became transparent... I'm still learning about the rendering::Visual class, not sure if there's an issue with Visual::SetMaterial or I'm just using it wrong. @iche033 ?

pullrequest.title: Building Editor: Pick wall / floor / stairs texture from a pre-set list on inspector

content.raw: I'm running into issues related to `rendering::Visual` as well (issue [1351](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1351/building-editor-crash-if-visual-scenenode)), though I'm not sure if it's a problem with the class itself or with how the Building Editor is handling its `VisualPtr`. I also suspect the highlighting problem you pointed out in [PR 1312](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1312/building-editor-improved-saving-pop-up) is related to `Visual`.
content.html: I'm running into issues related to rendering::Visual as well (issue 1351), though I'm not sure if it's a problem with the class itself or with how the Building Editor is handling its VisualPtr. I also suspect the highlighting problem you pointed out in PR 1312 is related to Visual.

pullrequest.title: Building Editor: Pick wall / floor / stairs texture from a pre-set list on inspector

content.raw: By the way, I didn't manage to make folding `Set3dTransparency` into `Set3dTexture` work, or even `visual->SetTransparency` right after `visual->SetMaterial`. The transparency value does change, but not the rendered visual. It seems that the transparency only sticks if set a while after, like when the user selects->deselects the item.
content.html: By the way, I didn't manage to make folding Set3dTransparency into Set3dTexture work, or even visual->SetTransparency right after visual->SetMaterial. The transparency value does change, but not the rendered visual. It seems that the transparency only sticks if set a while after, like when the user selects->deselects the item.

pullrequest.title: Building Editor: Pick wall / floor / stairs texture from a pre-set list on inspector

content.raw: Can you pull the textures from their installed location `GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH/media/materials/textures` instead of copying them into the GUI directory?
content.html: Can you pull the textures from their installed location GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH/media/materials/textures instead of copying them into the GUI directory?

pullrequest.title: Building Editor: Pick wall / floor / stairs texture from a pre-set list on inspector

content.raw: These are the thumbnails for the dropdown menu and soon for the palette icons as well. I'm not sure if I can refer to `GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH` on  `resources.qrc` - Can I?
content.html: These are the thumbnails for the dropdown menu and soon for the palette icons as well. I'm not sure if I can refer to GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH on resources.qrc - Can I?

pullrequest.title: Building Editor: Pick wall / floor / stairs texture from a pre-set list on inspector

content.raw:
I think you can do something like the following in resources.qrc:

  <file alias='wood.jpg'>../../media/materials/textures/wood.jpg</file>
  <file alias='ceiling.jpg'>../../media/materials/textures/ceiling_tiled.jpg</file>

Then refer to the images use ":wood.jpg" and ":ceiling.jpg".
content.html:
I think you can do something like the following in resources.qrc:

<file alias='wood.jpg'>../../media/materials/textures/wood.jpg</file> <file alias='ceiling.jpg'>../../media/materials/textures/ceiling_tiled.jpg</file>

Then refer to the images use ":wood.jpg" and ":ceiling.jpg".

pullrequest.title: Building Editor: Pick wall / floor / stairs texture from a pre-set list on inspector

content.raw: For the textures themselves I'm using existing material scripts from `gazebo / media / materials / scripts / gazebo.material`. That's why there are only 2 in this pull request. I plan to add the 3rd one, the bricks on the `hitl_usability` branch, to `gazebo.material`.
content.html: For the textures themselves I'm using existing material scripts from gazebo / media / materials / scripts / gazebo.material. That's why there are only 2 in this pull request. I plan to add the 3rd one, the bricks on the hitl_usability branch, to gazebo.material.
